event.title: was settled by Daniel Young, a blacksmith, in 1824

data.event: The site was settled by Daniel Young, a blacksmith, in 1824, and the place became known as "Young's Bluff".

In 1833, a road was constructed west from Young's Bluff to intersect the Robinson Road (which connected the cities of Columbus, Jackson, and Natchez, and is the second oldest road in Mississippi), and another was constructed east into Alabama.
Another early settler, Nimrod N. Nash, opened a store there, and then purchased Young's property in 1834.

In addition to the successful ferry service, Nashville's stores supplied local farmers with goods, it had a post office established in 1837, and its port had facilities to store cotton until steamboats arrived in the late autumn-early winter, when water level would rise.
